Package com.rb.nonbiz.types

Class PositiveEpsilon

java.lang.Object
java.lang.Number
com.rb.nonbiz.types.RBNumeric<T>
com.rb.nonbiz.types.ImpreciseValue<Epsilon>
com.rb.nonbiz.types.Epsilon
com.rb.nonbiz.types.PositiveEpsilon
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Comparable<Epsilon>
public class PositiveEpsilon
extends Epsilon
Represents an epsilon (small number) used to compare two numbers for 'rough equality', which must be strictly positive. i.e. if their values are 'close enough' subject to the epsilon.
See Also:

  • Method Details

    • positiveEpsilon

    • largePositiveEpsilon

      public static PositiveEpsilon largePositiveEpsilon​(double value)
      In certain rare cases, we want to have a larger epsilon. An example is net traded notional in an optimization of a portfolio with a very large value. In those cases, we can use this one to get around the limitation around the magnitude of the epsilon. The name is explicit enough, so there's a very low chance of messing up. We can't normally just remove preconditions from static constructors, but note that the size limitation here is really just a sanity check; it does not affect any behavior. That is, no code will look at the value of this and fail because it's > MAX_ALLOWED_EPSILON_VALUE.
